title: 108_s348
content: The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" establishes deductions for higher education expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act limits the amount allowed as a deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses for taxpayers in any taxable year. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" limits deductions for higher education expenses in taxable years 2003 and beyond to $8,000 and $12,000 respectively. The deduction amount is reduced based on modified adjusted gross income, with a threshold of $65,000 ($130,000 for joint returns). The deduction for higher education expenses is limited based on modified adjusted gross income, with thresholds of $65,000 ($130,000 for joint returns). Modified adjusted gross income is calculated without certain deductions and after applying specific tax sections. Adjusted gross income for specific tax sections is determined without certain deductions and after applying relevant tax provisions. Dollar amounts are subject to inflation adjustments for taxable years after 2003. The tax code allows for adjustments to income based on specific provisions and deductions, with dollar amounts subject to inflation adjustments for taxable years after 2003. Section 222 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include deductions for qualified tuition and related expenses of eligible students. Eligible student definitions are also revised in the code. The tax code is amended to allow deductions for qualified tuition and related expenses of eligible students. The definition of eligible student is updated, and the amendments made are permanent. These changes apply to payments made after December 31, 2002. The tax code is amended to allow deductions for qualified tuition and related expenses of eligible students, with changes applying to payments made after December 31, 2002. Additionally, a new section is added to provide a credit for interest on higher education loans. The tax code allows a credit for interest paid on qualified education loans, capped at $1,500, with reductions for higher income levels. The tax credit for interest on qualified education loans is reduced based on income levels, with adjustments for inflation starting in 2003. The tax credit for interest on qualified education loans is adjusted annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the year, with rounding rules applied. No credit is allowed if another taxpayer claims a deduction for the same individual. The credit is limited to the first 60 months of interest payments on a qualified education loan. The tax credit for interest on qualified education loans is limited to the first 60 months of payments. Special rules apply, such as no double benefit allowed and married couples must file a joint return to claim the credit. The tax credit for interest on qualified education loans is limited to the first 60 months of payments, and married couples must file a joint return to claim the credit. Marital status for tax purposes is determined according to section 7703 of the Internal Revenue Code. The tax credit for interest on qualified education loans is limited to the first 60 months of payments, and married couples must file a joint return to claim the credit. The amendments made by this section apply to any qualified education loan incurred on, before, or after the date of the enactment of this Act, but only with respect to any loan interest payment due after December 31, 2002.
